description:
Clostridium cavendishii DSM 21758 is an anaerobic, spore-forming, Gram-positive bacterium. It was isolated from a soil sample collected in the United Kingdom.

Some key scientific characteristics of this species:

1. Taxonomy: Clostridium cavendishii belongs to the genus Clostridium, which is a large and diverse group of anaerobic, spore-forming bacteria.

2. Morphology: Cells are rod-shaped, approximately 0.5-0.7 μm wide and 2.0-4.5 μm long. Spores are oval-shaped and located centrally or subterminally within the cells.

3. Physiology: C. cavendishii is an obligate anaerobe, meaning it can only grow in the absence of oxygen. It is mesophilic, with an optimal growth temperature range of 30-37°C.

4. Metabolism: The bacterium is saccharolytic, capable of fermenting various carbohydrates to produce organic acids, such as acetic acid and butyric acid, as the main end products.

5. Habitat and Ecology: C. cavendishii is a soil-dwelling bacterium, commonly found in terrestrial environments. It may play a role in the decomposition of organic matter in the environment.

6. Genome: The complete genome sequence of C. cavendishii DSM 21758 has been determined, providing insights into its genetic makeup and potential metabolic capabilities.

This brief overview highlights some of the key scientific characteristics of the Clostridium cavendishii DSM 21758 strain, which can be further explored through more detailed studies and research.
